data.title: The late Queen Rambhai Barni

data.text:
BANGKOK, Thailand -- The late Queen Rambhai Barni - granddaughter of the king of Siam portrayed in the musical, 'The King and I' -- was cremated Tuesday in a spectacular $1 million royal funeral ceremony complete with booming cannons and chanting monks.

Queen Rambhai was the granddaughter of King Mongkut, Rama IV, who died in 1868 and whose life was portrayed in the famed Broadway musical and a later movie, both starring actor Yul Brynner. She was also Thailand's last link to the days of absolute monarchy.

With hundreds of thousands of Thai citizens looking on, the queen's remains were brought 2 miles to the cremation grounds on an ancient 40-ton funeral carriage slowly pulled by 400 men.

Cannons boomed every minute along the procession route. While the route itself was short, many in the crowd who had waited hours for the event fainted in the sweltering 97-degree heat.

Queen Rambhai died of a heart attack May 22, 1984, at the age of 79. The cremation was delayed for nearly a year to prepare for the ceremony.

The tradition-rich rites began shortly after dawn and ended at sunset with the lighting of a sacred fire as bugles, drums and conches sounded and an honor guard played Last Post.

Scores of Buddhist monks chanted and read ancient scriptures as King and Queen Sirikit presided over the religious ceremony and the royal pyre was lit.

The funeral procession lasted five hours and included five battalions of soldiers in scarlet tunics, hundreds of government officials in white dress uniforms and royal pages clad in ancient costumes.

The gilded 59-foot-high funeral carriage, the 'Royal Great Victory Chariot,' is regarded as one of Thailand's most beautiful works of art and normally is housed in the National Museum.

Renovation of the funeral carriage, construction of 95-foot high wooden crematorium and other preparations for the royal ceremony -- the first one ince 1954 -- cost $1 million.

Queen Rambhai was the wife of King Rama VII, who died in self-imposed exile in England in 1941. She was the aunt of King Bhumibol, also known as King Rama IX, and a granddaughter of King Mongkut, Rama IV.

The late queen's husband was on the throne in 1932 when a coup changed the nation, then known as Siam, from an absolute monarchy to a constitutional democracy.

The king accepted the takeover to avoid bloodshed, but two years later left the country for self-imposed exile in England, where he abdicated the throne in 1935.

Queen Rambhai remained in England until 1949, when she returned to Thailand with her husband's ashes. She was known for her many charitable works, her good humor and her love for the game of golf.
